Recode Human-Readable Labels to REDCap Dictionary Codes

recode_data.Rd

This function maps human-readable values in a dataset back to their corresponding REDCap dictionary codes using a named list of field-specific dictionaries. It is useful when REDCap exports or manually curated data use labels, but the system requires coded values.

Usage

recode_data(dicts, dayta)

Arguments

dicts

A named list of dictionaries (typically from read_and_parse_dict), where each element corresponds to a REDCap field and contains a named character vector of code-to-label mappings.

dayta

A data frame or tibble with label values (to be converted back to codes).

Value

A tibble with the same structure as dayta, but with dictionary-mapped values replaced by their corresponding REDCap codes where applicable.

Details

Only columns that exist in both dayta and dicts are considered. Any unmatched values (either due to typos, unexpected entries, or blanks) are flagged in the console output.

For each applicable column:

  • The dictionary is reversed (label → code)

  • Each label in the data is matched to its code

  • If labels are not matched (e.g. due to typos or blanks), a warning message is shown

  • Unmatched values are left as NA in the output

Examples

dicts <- list(
  fat = c("0" = "Negative", "1" = "Positive"),
  sample_buffer = c("0" = "Glycerol-saline", "1" = "RNAlater")
)

df <- tibble::tibble(
  fat = c("Positive", "Negative", "Unknown"),
  sample_buffer = c("RNAlater", "Glycerol-saline", "")
)

recoded <- recode_data(dicts, df)
#> ⚠️ Some values could not be matched to dictionary codes.
#> → Please review and replace these in your data to match allowed dictionary values.
#>  - `fat`: Unknown
#>  - `sample_buffer`: contains blanks
print(recoded)
#> # A tibble: 3 × 2
#>   fat   sample_buffer
#>   <chr> <chr>        
#> 1 1     1            
#> 2 0     0            
#> 3 NA    NA
